bug.short_desc: Some source paths too long in SDK builds

long_desc.thetext:
Due to fair means or foul, we sometimes end up with "source" directory names that are too long for some operating systems (or, the unzip programs used on them).
One example is in sse.core, we have a "DevTimeSupport" directory with some parser generator input files and utiliities in it.
While not fatal, the error messages receieved during unzip might be interpreted as "somethings wrong with the zip file", so we should strive to correct these.
One possibility is to omit from SDK per se, but leave a small note there on were to get from CVS. Practically speaking, this would satisfy the need, since the need for these files is almost zero (only a few developers would ever be interested ... they are not used during normal, every day debuggin).
Another, I'll experiment with, is declaring DevTimeSupport a "source folder" so it gets zipped up in the src.zip file. This will require, also, a specification to exclude its contents from the compile part of the build, since we don't want the 'java' files, etc., that are there to actually be compiled in that spot (typically these java files are the output of the parser generator, and they are copied to another spot in the source directories, once ready to include them in a build).

I couldn't seem to the the "source folder" stuff to work easily, so, just removed the scripts, etc., from the SDK build ... but, left the directory and a note of what to find in that directory by going to cvs.
This is part of a "mass update" where bugs showing "fixed" between 7/1/2006 and 9/27/2006 are assumed fixed in WTP 1.5.1. feel free to change the target milestone if you know a more accurate setting.

This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP defects already verified by the reporter but awaiting closure by the assignee. If you feel this defect was closed inappropriately, please reopen.
Thanks, John Lanuti

bug.short_desc: Search for Java method too restrictive

long_desc.thetext: In an EMF model, it is not possible to call a Java method with primitive type parameters on a model object. For example, I have an ATL transformation that creates as output a UML profile. To create extensions I want to call the stereotype method createExtension(org.eclipse.uml2.uml.Class metaclass, boolean isRequired). ATL can't find this method, but if I change the method to take a Boolean parameter it works.

Created an attachment (id=49799) Match primitive types and wrapper classes.
This is what I did to make it work for me. I don't know if all the types can actually occur in ATL.

Integrated patch.
Thanks ;-)

attachment.desc: Match primitive types and wrapper classes.

bug.short_desc: Copying a project in Navigator view deletes all parallel directories

long_desc.thetext: In the Navigator view I copied a project (Ctrl-c/Ctrl-v). In the dialog I entered the parent directory (of the copied project) and a new name for the project. All directories under the parent directory were deleted (including the copied project directory).
Move to Platform/Resources

I can't reproduce this. If I select the parent directory (the workspace location), then the copy fails with the message "Invalid project description. d:\workspace overlaps the workspace location: d:\workspace". Nothing gets deleted. Are you using the final Eclipse 3.2 release?
*** Bug 156804 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I tried to reproduce this today. I was able to copy and paste a project into the same workspace successfully once (copied project is parallel to the original project). I deleted the copied project and tried to copy the same project again. The Copy Project dialog always shows "Invalid Location Path" even when I use the wizzard to create a new directory for it. I was using the same location and project name for the copied project as in the first successful attempt.
I had this same problem with the Copy Project wizzard when I first reported this bug. I had to go through some machinations to finally get it to copy the project without complaining about the path. It could have been something I did while trying to get the Copy Project dialog to cooperate that led to it deleting parallel projects.
Note that I use a different directory for my workspace and the source code for my projects. I added all the projects into the workspace with the New Project wizzard.
Yes, I'm using the 3.2 final release.

The only explanation i can think of is that you set the location of the copied project to be the parent directory of the original project. Then, deleting that copied project would in fact delete all directories parallel to the original project.
I can't reproduce your "Invalid Location Path" problem in the project copy dialog either. However, I can see that the wizard has some problems - by default it does not change the location of the copied project, so the copy will always fail unless you change the location manually. Also, it should validate the location and not allow you to push "ok" until a valid location is entered. I'll enter a bug against the UI for this.

I have entered bug 164695 for the problematic behaviour of the copy dialog. I'm going to close this as invalid as I don't have a test case to reproduce. If you can reproduce, please provide exact steps.

bug.short_desc: Copying a project in Navigator copies all projects in the workspace into the new project

long_desc.thetext:
I copy a project in Navigator (Ctrl-c/Ctrl-v). In the dialog I enter the parent directory of the copied project and enter a new name for the new project. The new project contains all existing projects in the workspace.
The copy project functionality in Navigator seems to be badly broken. Also see bug # 156803.
Sounds like Resources.
When I deleted the copied project (containing all projects in the workspace) it also deleted all the projects in the workspace. Dangerous.

I can't see any difference between this bug and bug 156803. Closing.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 156803 ***

bug.short_desc: Project 'refresh' not working on updated project workspace after ANT build

long_desc.thetext: After running an ANT build on my Project, the build creates new subdirectories and files for the project. I use File Explore to verify that the subdir's & files are created in the workspace. But when I try to 'refresh' the project under the IDE package explorer, the new dir's & files do not show up in the project (I also don't see a refresh window popup).
Hmm, works for me... Sorry if this is obvious, but F5 is not bound to refresh in the Package Explorer. You need to select Refresh from the project context menu.

Dave, could you answer my question above? Anything else unusual about your ant script worth noting? Note that you can also configure it to refresh the workspace automatically after running an Ant script from the Ant launch dialog - see the "Refresh" tab.
Unable to reproduce.

bug.short_desc: ServerDefinitionTypeTest goes haywire

long_desc.thetext:
I suspect this is a special case type failure, but I've seen some problem issues lately, in "head builds" where this unit test goes "crazy" prints a bunch of messages to the console (I'll attach) and eventually an "out of memory" error stops all the tests.
jst.server.generic.tests.ServerDefinitionTypeTest.testEclipseVarResolve

Created an attachment (id=49800) snippet of console messages before out of memory error
I'm not sure what goes "hay wire" here, but seems as though we should have gaurds against it.

David, I am not sure which build is this on 1.5 or 2.0 stream or are you using the HEAD for all the plugins. The problematic test is a new one targeting a new feature for 2.0 stream but it seems to run OK in my environment.

Gorkem, its for the HEAD of the 2.0 stream (and, yes, HEAD of all, just like a "nightly build".
I'm a little relieved somehow to hear it is a "new" test :)
I'm not too surpised to hear it runs ok in your environment, as our build machine is a bit "special". I was hoping something obvious might be apparent to those familar with the code to either bullet proof it, or, perhaps to print out some improved diagnostics.
For example, even if the test ended up 'passing', it appears from one of the traces that resolvePropertiesFromCache is recursively called over 600 times. Is that normal? Seems like very deep recursion, perhaps too deep for code to perform well? If that's the right design, fine. If, instead, you are not expecting that, you could, perhaps, put in some 'recursion depth' checks?

Yep I have noticed that recursion trace as well. The code can go pretty deep when trying to resolve a string that has many properties but 600 is more than expected especially with my test string. This probably indicates a problem, I will investigate and resolve.
David, I can not repro the same trace in my environment. Recursion does not go any deeper than 2 with the test. Is it still possible to do HEAD builds so that I can investigate further.
Test is no longer valid.

bug.short_desc: plugin.properties not found if runtime is stand-alone

long_desc.thetext:
Problem: Failure to load plugin.property ressources in a stand-alone setup.
Fix is easy and is provided below.
Reproducibility: The problem does not exist when run in Eclipse. The problem happen only when stand-alone and the EMF library is not in a .jar file. This is because, depending of the context, not the same logic is used to access the plugin.properties.
Bug: In EMFPlugin.class, function getBaseURL, the following line of code is adding an extra slash to the baseURL:
baseURL = new URL(uri.trimSegments(1).toString() + "/");
This cause the URL to have two trailing "//" in its path and causes the access to fail.
On my setup, it works when changing the code to:
baseURL = new URL(uri.trimSegments(1).toString());
Suggested fix: The code should not add an extra "/" if there is already a trailing one in the result from the "uri.trimSegments(1).toString()" step.
Regards,
\Mario Fortier

Here is additional info.
In my setup, the following EMF code is how the properties are to be accessed:
// If the bundle can't be found the normal way, try to find it as the base URL. // If that also doesn't work, rethrow the original exception. // try { InputStream inputStream = new URL(getBaseURL().toString()+ "plugin.properties").openStream(); bundle = untranslatedResourceBundle = resourceBundle = new PropertyResourceBundle(inputStream); inputStream.close(); }
The runtime environment is on .NET. All the .jar are transformed into .DLL using IKVM. The resulting URL to access the properties is:
"ikvmres://org_eclipse_emf_ecore,%20Version=0.0.0.1,%20Culture=neutral,20PublicKeyToken=null//plugin.properties"
The extra slash comes from getBaseURL() at the following line: baseURL = new URL(uri.trimSegments(1).toString() + "/");
When the appending of the extra slash is removed, it works.
The problem is reproducible with the following code: Diagnostician validator = Diagnostician.INSTANCE; Diagnostic diagnostic = validator.validate(_layout);
(_layout is from my model instance)
I then get a MissingRessourceException: The string resource '_UI_DiagnosticRoot_diagnostic' could not be located'.
=== You can download my setup to reproduce the problem here:
http://www.ta-lib.org/rdata/TestEMF.zip (Warning: The size is about 195 Megs)
Perl and VS2005 are not included.
Directory Description ===================== Private\Chart\TestApp : A simplified VS2005 console app causing the exception. Private\Chart\Model : The directory from which I generate the DLL (with do.pl)
Private\EclipseModeler : The workspace for generating msmodel.jar (the model).
OpenSource\IKVM : Tool used by "do.pl". OpenSource\EclipseModeler : My Eclipse 3.2. "do.pl" uses many .jar from this directory.
Suggestion ========== To avoid any potential breaking change, may be just a logic to check if there is already a trailing slash before appending a new one would make it work for all cases.
It seems that the only place where such logic would be needed is for the following line in getBaseURL: baseURL = new URL(uri.trimSegments(1).toString() + "/");
Do not hesitate if you need further info, this is important to me.
\Mario

Created an attachment (id=49823) Patch to check for ending in "/"
So I assume that the original tested URI would have been
ikvmres://org_eclipse_emf_ecore,%20Version=0.0.0.1,%20Culture=neutral,20PublicKeyToken=null/plugin.properties
Doing trimFragments(1) on this produces
ikvmres://org_eclipse_emf_ecore,%20Version=0.0.0.1,%20Culture=neutral,20PublicKeyToken=null/
and appending another "/" to that doesn't produce a good result as you've noticed.
Exactly. BTW, please not that the trimSegments(1) + "/" code sequence occurs in two other places in that file as well, it may be a good idea to factor that code into a helper method.

Only one other place does the append of the "/" and that's in the case that the plugin.properties was found relative of the plugin class and since we don't support generating classes without a package, there must be at least one level of package nesting in this other case, so probably it's fine as is...

What you're trying to do looks a lot like URI.createURI(".").resolve(uri)
I don't suppose we know that is absolute, do we?
I would certainly expect it would be absolute, but I'm not sure it's guarenteed.

The proposed patch looks good to me.
Looking forward to the next Maintenance Build.
Many Thanks.
\Mario

Dave,
Actually, since we are for sure creating a URL and a URL requires a registered scheme/protocol, I suppose it will for sure be absolute and hence the resolve against "." does seem good.

Created an attachment (id=50079) Patch to resolve against "."
I'll commit the change in this patch which uses the approach Dave recommended.
The changes have been committed to CVS.

I have tested 2.2.1RC1 (S200609141116) on my setup and it now works.
Thanks all,
\Mario

attachment.desc: Patch to check for ending in "/"

bug.short_desc: [gmfgraph] EMF Editor for gmfgraph should display copy-pasted TemplatePoints consistently

long_desc.thetext:
To reproduce this, open gmfgraph resource in EMF-generated editor. 1. Create Polyline 2. Create template point, set x = 1, y = 2 => It is shown as (1, 2), that's OK. 3. Copy point and paste it into the same polyline => New point is shown as "Location: (1, 2)"
Expected -- both points are shown with same notation.

Expected behaviour of default emf editor (((
Template point is copied but when it is pasted it's not known which feature value should be updated - I guess that the first available is considered and this happens to be figure location instead of template points thus another label. I don't think that we should fix this; better use dedicated editor generated by gmf that won't have such limitations.
Instead of fixing this particular problem fix the general flaw: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=157074

bug.short_desc: picles swim in navigator pane

long_desc.thetext:
As you move the mouse up and down over the file names in the navigor pane, the names "swim" upward by one pixel as the mouse moves over and the item is highlighted in yellow. This makes me feel dizzy and looks wrong.
This effect occurrs only when the names are long enough to be truncated at the right, and is most obvious when the name are long.

Created an attachment (id=49805) sample text image
compare the relative position of the text "catalastrings" in the yellow box to the same text without the box.
What is your build id (see Help->About)? What platform are you using? Windows XP?
Also, which view are you referring to? Navigator, Package Explorer, Project Explorer?

This is native Windows behaviour. Try the same in the Windows Explorer - open it and let is display folders, then make the folders pane narrower than the folder names and hover over them with the mouse. Closing as wontfix.

Build id: M20060629-1905
As for this being windows native behavior, nonsense. I guarantee I would have noticed it if seen anywhere else, and this yellow highlighting is definitely seen only in eclipse.

Whenever there is not enough room to fully display the text of an item in a table or tree, Windows shows a tool tip with that text so the user can see it without having to resize the widget. I don't think that the OS gives any guarantees as to which location the tool tip will pop up at.
my complaint is not about the tool tip. My complaint is about the position of the actual text inside the yellow box. See the attachment.

OK, but I would think that the text position inside the tool tip is pretty much fixed, and it's the location of the tool tip itself that decides whether or not the tool tip text will end up being exactly on top of the truncated item text.
Also, I can confirm that on my system there's no difference between Eclipse and Windows Explorer in this respect.
That being said, the one-pixel movement didn't happen when the tree items in Eclipse still had their old height (see bug 117201).
Created an attachment (id=49901) screenshot of Windows Explorer with tooltip

(In reply to comment #5) > As for this being windows native behavior, nonsense.
Closing again. See screenshot. If you care to reopen this again, please change the component to SWT.

attachment.desc: screenshot of Windows Explorer with tooltip

Bugzilla is used at Eclipse.org to report bugs and feature requests for the Eclipse projects. You selected a product/component for reporting bugs and feature request for Eclipse's Bugzilla itself.
Anyway, questions like yours should be asked on the newsgroups first. Please go to http://www.eclipse.org/newsgroups/ and read through the descriptions and request a password. You might want to ask your question in the eclipse.platform newsgroup.
news://news.eclipse.org/eclipse.platform http://www.eclipse.org/newsportal/thread.php?group=eclipse.platform
closing

bug.short_desc: can't ignore files

long_desc.thetext: Not all projects are perfectly tidy. There ought to be a way to mark files as "ignored by this project" even if they would normally be processed. At present the only way to do this is to delete the file. I ought to be able to say ignore "oldversion.java" and have it stick.
Ignored as in not shown in the UI, or as in not looked at by the compiler?

At least ignored by the compiler. Ignored by the UI would have to be an option, because there would have to be a way to un-ignore a file too. It would be handy to create an "ignored files" folder, which would just designate a set of files, not move them into a subdirectory.
Moving to Resources.

You want the files to be ignored by which compiler? The Java compiler has this option by adding exclusion filters on the Java Build Path property page, from the Source tab. If this doesn't do the trick, please be very clear about what should be ignoring the file, and what shouldn't be ignoring the file. Should they be ignored by search? Should they appear in the Navigator, etc?
yes, this is the functionality I was looking for. I think it would be adequate if this obscure placement were made more acessable, perhaps as a click-right option on the file name.
Actually, now that I check, it is in the context menu. Right click on a file or directory in the package explorer view, and choose Build Path > Exclude.

bug.short_desc: [nls tooling] Externalizes strings dialog has wrong buttons enabled

long_desc.thetext:
If you have only one string to externalize, open the Externalizes Strings Wizard. All the three buttons (Externalize, Ignore, Internalize) are enabled. But if you click on one of them, nothing happens besides they get disabled because the no string in the table is selected when the dialog opens. Now we have to ways: a) disable them at startuo if nothing is selected b) select the first entry automatically if there is only one entry
In my eyes, option b) is the better approach to have a smart user interaction.
I'll provide a patch for the second way tomorrow if nobody has a problem with this.
Fixed in HEAD. Available in builds > N20060911-0010.

bug.short_desc: Incorrect mouse pointer feedback for zero-width non-resizable Table columns

long_desc.thetext:
When user attempts to resize a column immediately to the left of a zero-width non-resizable column by dragging the separator in the table header, one often hits an area where resizing does not work while the mouse pointer suggests that it is possible.
To reproduce: Create a Table with three columns, A, B and C. Programmatically hide column B by setting it to 0-width non-resizable (columnB.setResizable(false); columnB.setWidth(0)). 1) Position the mouse pointer on the table header separator between A and C so that the column header A is highlighted. The mouse pointer becomes <-|->. 2) Move the mouse pointer a few pixels to the right until the column header A is no longer highlighted. The mouse pointer changes from <-|-> to <-||->. 3) Try to click and drag -- nothing happens.

The problem you describe should be fixed by the recent changes made for bug 9401. Using the latest version of SWT, the column-reveal cursor (<-||->) does not appear anymore for non-resizable zero-width columns.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 9401 ***

bug.short_desc: Tree: Sort column background missing for Classic Theme

long_desc.thetext: Created an attachment (id=49810) Screenshot (Classic vs. Luna)

Just removing the IsAppThemed() calls isn't enough. There are bugs/features in the old version of the tree that don't allow you to draw behind the +/- expanders. Also, there are redraw issues when the sort indicator is changed.
Fixing this is a low priority for me.

(In reply to comment #2) > Just removing the IsAppThemed() calls isn't enough.
Oh, okay. I tried out various stuff in the Tree tab of the control example after commenting out the relevant IsAppThemed checks and didn't find any obvious problems.
The columns don't redraw when you move the sort indicator.

> The columns don't redraw when you move the sort indicator.
They seem to do for me, but I'm now able to see the other problem you mentioned. You're right, the background of the tree line/expander area isn't filled with the sort colour when FULL_SELECTION is off. Not sure why I missed it the first time.

Created an attachment (id=50061) Test changes
Here are the quickly-hacked test changes that I used (they may be bogus).
(In reply to comment #5) > You're right, the background of the tree line/expander > area isn't filled with the sort colour when FULL_SELECTION is off. > Not sure why I missed it the first time.
Please ignore that part. The background of the +/- box is indeed not filled with the sort colour (is that a problem?) but the rest was just due to accidentally running the test with one IsAppThemed call left intact. Sorry about that.
I'm considering removing the sort column background on table to be consistent. I don't think I can fix tree. Your thoughts?

bug.short_desc: frequent logged excepitons when running JUnit tests

long_desc.thetext:
I see the attached exceptions in my log nearly every time I run our JUnit tests in my dev. env.
Are these tests supposed to throw exceptions? To prove that throwing exceptions really works?

Created an attachment (id=49811) console output during unit tests
The tests I'm referring to are are MasterListTestSuite, that can be found wst/components/sse/development/org.eclipse.wst.sse.unittests.
My guess is there is some validation jobs still running while the workbench is shutting down, so the code just needs better protection ... such as if bundle is null, or not "active" and "install", then ... do not try to call bundle.loadClass(classname);
make sense?
This looks like it belongs in the xml component

bug.short_desc: API needed for controlling Table column visibility

long_desc.thetext: Hiding a column programmatically is currently possible by setting the column width to 0 and making it non-resizable. However, there are two drawbacks with this approach: 1) It becomes a programmers responsibility to store and restore the column width to what it was before the column was hidden. 2) There is currently an issue with incorrect mouse pointer feedback with this method, which results in a confusing user experience on Windows XP: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=156823
Bug 86460 contained the same request (and was marked as WONTFIX).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 86460 ***

bug.short_desc: One step forward, two steps back

long_desc.thetext:
After adding the browser widget to the New Extension dialog and giving it a white background, the info proposal box for the content assist is now half yellow and half white.
The latter now also comes with F2 support, which does not work. I suspect F2 does not work with this functionality by design, since JDT does not have it.
Thanks, removed f2 info string and changed color.

bug.short_desc: [Sync Info] Refreshing on linked folder deletes its CVS folders

long_desc.thetext:
There already exists a general project with CVS connected, named as "phone".
Now, Checkout a new general project, named as "addrbook".
Use command line terminal to create a soft link to connect the root of project "addrbook" to a new folder "addr" in project "phone". The command in Windows 200 would be: *\phone\> linkd addr ..\addrbook (Require Windows 2000 Resource Toolkits) Or in linux box, use "ln -s ...".
Now, refresh the project "phone", a new folder of "addr" will be displayed. But after "refresh" action is performed. Now refresh project "addrbook", all the CVS information is gone. Check the file system, CVS folder and sub CVS folders under addrbook are deleted.
I don't think refreshing a folder/project have the right to remove those CVS folders quietly if they are detected as implicitly checked out (linked folder) into the project.
BTW: Check out a CVS project into an existed CVS project and refereshing that folder does not remove anything about CVS, which is correct. And Eclipse's link folder is not tested in my case.
This problem also occurs when the project have 2 or more src dirs from different CVS roots.

When you say "linked" you mean the OS version of that correct? There is the notion of linked folders at the Eclipse level and CVS makes sure not to purge the CVS folders from that type of link. If we had the ability to determine if a folder was an OS link, we could avoid purging in that case as well. John, did I hear it mentioned that this was in the works?
Detecting/handling OS links at the resource or filesystem level isn't currently planned.
There's not much we can do at thbis time then.

bug.short_desc: Ad-hoc SQL not executed by vendor provided ExecutionService

long_desc.thetext:
Steps to reproduce
1. Create a SQL file using File->New->SQL Development->SQL File 2. Add some sql statements to the file 3. Right-click on editor, select "Set Connection Info" and select the profile to match current connection. 4. Select some statements using mouse/drag 5. right-click on selection and select either "Execute All" or "Execute Selected Text". 6. The selected statement gets executed by the default class, SimpleSQLResultRunnable, than the ExecutionService provided by the vendor plugin.
This makes it difficult to profile the execution using execution plan and any such pre/post execution tasks.
Hui, Let's look at this for 1.0 -- it seems like a pretty serious limitation.
Fixed. When executing sql statement, customized SimpleSQLResultRunnable is used if provided.
closed.

bug.short_desc: IDocument get() can return null?

long_desc.thetext:
I've seen NPE's pop up in my unit tests from time to time in handleFileContentChanged method of ResourceTextFileBuffer, in the code section
String newContent= document.get(); boolean replaceContent= !newContent.equals(fDocument.get());
I'm not even sure which implementation of document is being used, but, when I went to look at the API spec of 'get' if wasn't clear if it was supposed to return empty string, or null, if there was no content in the document.
BTW, in case you're wondering, the context was some CharsetDeltaJob and since it doesn't often show up, I suspect its some rare timing thing ... maybe part of the workbench is already shutting down while this Job is in the que.
So ... I'm mostly asking for a clear spec on IDocuemnt's get method ... emptyString? never null? Or, is this one of those cases that's covered by some general rule I can remember (like null never returned unless its spec'd?).
Much thanks.

Hi David, it should never return 'null'.
From the API Rules of Engagement: >Assume everything is non-null unless the API specification says otherwise. ==> IDocument.get() says nothing ==> must not return null.
If you get 'null' then it is a bug in the implementation and should be reported against the implementer.
Is it really document.get() that is null and not eventually the ITextFileBuffer.getDocument()? This could happen if someone uses the buffer after it has been disposed. This indeed can happen if people run jobs while shutting down the workspace.

bug.short_desc: Radio ToolItem Selection Event problem

long_desc.thetext:
I am not totally sure, but I think I am also seeing this for MenuItems with Radio-Style. I always end checking if the MenuItem really has selection from the selection-listener-implementation, since I get one event for the old and one event for the new selected item.
Ben

I don't think there's a bug here, because:
- starting with item X selected and then clicking on item Y should fire Selection events for item X (its deselection) and item Y (its selection), which is what I see - programmatically selecting an item should not fire a Selection event for the newly-selected or newly-unselected items, because programmatic changes do not generally fire events (this is documented in one of the SWT articles)
So the "delayed" selection event for item 0 that you're seeing when item 1 is pressed is actually the deselection of item 0, not the delayed selection of item 0 from the previous item0.setSelection(true) call.
Closing report. If I've misunderstood an aspect of your description and you still think there's a bug here then please reopen this report, thanks.

bug.short_desc: [Webapp] Cannot access Help Server over IPv6

long_desc.thetext:
I cannot setup a HTTP Server over IPv6, it's works fine on my IPv4 environment, pls see my recreate steps:
1. IPv6 Environment: Machine A: IPv6 IP: 2001:db8:0:2:250:8dff:fe83:10e6 Machine B: IPv6 IP: 2001:db8:0:2:20d:60ff:fee7:ea45
2. Since we have no DNS Server is created, add following to C:\Windows\system32\drivers\etc\hosts to each machines: 2001:db8:0:2:250:8dff:fe83:10e6 test1 2001:db8:0:2:20d:60ff:fee7:ea45 test2
3. Bring up Eclipse 3.2 RC7 on machine A, click Help->Help Contents to start Help Server
4. Press Ctrl+N to check the Port of Help Server
5. Access this server on machine B via URL http://test1:$Port/help/index.jsp. -->Failed, cannot browse Help contents.
6. Additional Info: On the other hand, the URL http://[2001:db8:0:2:250:8dff:fe83:10e6]:$Port/help/index.jsp cannot access help Server too.

Please check the latest Eclipse platform to see whether it works or not. If not, a bug should be filed against the Eclipse platform.
Also why is Eclipse 3.2 RC 7 been used?
Are we doing anything for 3.3 ?

Hi Jiang,
Are you able to try this using 3.3 M7? We switched away from using Tomcat in that milestone and I would be interested to know if the problem still exists. If it does not show up in 3.3M7 I would suspect that it is a limitation in Tomcat.

Hi Jiang,
One more question - are you using Windows XP? The reason I ask is that we have recently seen problems loading help on Windows 2003 Server.

Hi Chris,
Sorry for my later response.
Yes, I'm using Windows XP with SP2 for this testing. I have tried on Eclipse 3.3.0 N20070413-0010 build, unfortunately I still cannot access the HTTP Server over IPv6 network.

Reproduced using I20070508-0800.
I did not map a hostname to the IPv6 address as outlined in step 2. I simply entered the URL directly as in step 6. I also confirmed that I'm able to ping the machine hosting help using the IPv6 address and that I can access the infocenter remotely using the IPv4 URL.
Further investigation to follow.

I just managed to get this working by targetting the IPv6 address for my local machine running help. I don't believe there is any problem with help, I think the issue is with the configuration of the network. It took me a while to get any useful results myself.
Jiang, are you running an IPv4 network and using the 6to4 tunneling pseudo-interface? If that's the case I suspect that the packets flagged with the IPv6 addresses are being dropped before they get to the machine that is serving help. I'm no expert in the area, so this is mostly an educated guess. Also, make sure you are using IE7 as IE6 does not support IPv6 (I learned this the hard way).
To see this for yourself, try going to http://test1:$Port/help/index.jsp or http://[2001:db8:0:2:250:8dff:fe83:10e6]:$Port/help/index.jsp on machine A (assuming you are under the same configuration as when you originally reported the bug). I suspect you will find this works.

For more information and insight as to where I'm coming from on this. Check out the problem titled "Tunneled traffic is not reaching the destination." at the following URL:
http://technet2.microsoft.com/windowsserver/en/library/7f077480-123d-4325-8369-dbca825151811033.mspx?mfr=true
The problem titled "Unable to reach other 6to4 sites or the IPv6 Internet by using the 6to4 router." also has some useful information.
I also found the following resource very useful for general information about IPv6:
http://www.microsoft.com/technet/network/ipv6/ipv6faq.mspx
Based on Adam's comments I'm going to close this as we are able to get the help system to work using ipV6.

bug.short_desc: Plugin.xml editor UI corrupted when a target platform is set

long_desc.thetext:
At first just the right behavior:
I have my plugin.xml opened in the editor. In the Extensions - All extensions I have org.eclipse.ui.views node. When I right-click and choose New > I see: - category - view - stickyView
For a concrete view properties I see browse button for class and icon
And now the wrong behavior caused by selecting a target for Plugin development: - I use downloaded eclipse-RCP-3.2-win32.zip Window > Preferences > Plug-in development > Target Platform I choose the dir with eclipse from downloaded RCP file.
And suddenly in the plugin.xml editor if a do the same as I mentioned above I can see in the context menu only: New > generic
In a view properties, there is no browse button, no clickble "class" label and sometimes some fields are missing. And the last text input field does't have a bottom border.
If I set the Target platform back to the current eclipse IDE dir, it works fine again.
Wenca

The RCP binary download does not contain the source plug-ins that contain the extension point schemas. Without these schemas, PDE is unable to populate the context menus of the plug-in editor.
If you want to target an RCP build and take advantage of PDE's capabilities, you need to download the "RCP SDK" from the same download page.

bug.short_desc: [History View] History view not refreshed after sharing project

long_desc.thetext: Open a file in a previous shared project and view its history. Reattach the project using Team>Share... The history view does not update, even after clicking its refresh button -- you have to switch to another file's history, then back again.
The CVS history view would need to listner for projectConfigured events from ResourceStateChangeListeners. There is currently no plan to address this item but patches will be accepted.
Thanks for the pointers. If I get the time, I shall see if I can do anything about it.

I think this is a bit more complicated than just adding a listener, because there are actually two kinds of HistoryPage in use - CVSHistoryPage(for versioned items) and LocalHistoryPage (for non-versioned). The problem is, that one is opened, (de)configuring project is necessary to switch from one to another, but the viewer is in another plugin (GenericHistoryView), so it cannot be done in easy way (cyclic dependencies).
I see only one path: Add callback mechanism to GenericHistoryView. 1. history page, when notices the project (de)configuration checks if the resource is affected. 2. if yes, calls GenericHistoryView to close it, and open new one.
How does it sound? Is there another way?

There is a RepositoryProviderManager that is internal to Team. The GenericHistoryView could listen to the manager for provider change events. If the provider for the project of a resource being shown in the History View changes, the history view could reobtain the history page source and, from that source, get a new page. We would only want to do this if a page source wasn't explicitly provided when the history view was populated.

bug.short_desc: JSP parser does not parse custom tags correctly within <SCRIPT>

long_desc.thetext:
Hello everyone,
I am using the offical WTP 1.5.0 release. WTP did incorrectly show errors in some jsps of a project, but the jsps are working fine in my j2ee application server.
I tracked this bug down to a minimalistic example which is using one custom tag. Please have a look at the attachment.
The project defines a custom taglib "Test" with one tag "Test". This tag has one property with rtexprvalue set to true.
If we are using two of this tags within a <script> tag and using jsp expressions then the jsp validator seems not to work correctly. Some valid regions will be parsed as an error and vice versa.
Please have a look at the commented source:
<%@ page import="test.TestTag" %> <%@ taglib uri="Test" prefix="test" %>
<%! final static byte[] tableRow = {0} ; // wtp shows error: "Syntax error, insert "}" to complete ClassBody" %> <HTML>
<test:Tag errorCode="<%=TestTag.A%>" /> // wtp does _sometimes_ not allow to "surf" to this variable using the ctrl key <test:Tag errorCode="<%=TestTag.B%>" /> <test:Tag errorCode="<%=TestTag.C%>" /> // wtp does not show this as an error <test:Tag errorCode="<%=Doesnotexist%>" /> // wtp does not show this as an error <script> <test:Tag errorCode="<%=TestTag.A%>" /> // These tags are causing the troubles, if you remove one of them, or remove one of the jsp expressions <test:Tag errorCode="<%=TestTag.B%>" /> // everything will be parsed correctly </script> </HTML>
Best Regards, Patric Rufflar
Created an attachment (id=49819) minimalistic WTP project to reproduce the error

attachment.desc: minimalistic WTP project to reproduce the error

bug.short_desc: [DND] XML editor "infects" ongoing drag with its contents

long_desc.thetext:
I experience the following weird behavior:
I have a file "data.xml" open in the XML editor. Then I do the following drag-and-drop action (without rleasing the mouse button): - I start dragging another file "readme.txt" from the Package Explorer - I move over the XML editor - I move over the Firefox button sitting in my Windows Task bar - Firefox isrestored - I drop the file into Firefox
I do not get the contents of the file I started dragging ("readme.txt") but the contents of the file that is open in the XML editor ("data.xml").
When I drag the file directly (without moving over the XML editor) the correct contents are opened.
I also tested the following variations: - The problem does not occur with any other editor. Only the XML editor 'infects' the drag operation. - The problem does not occur when the drag starts in the Navigator view. Only the Package Explorer triggers the behavior. - Replacing Firefox by any other windows application gives the same results. So Firefox is probably not the cause.
Which page were you dragging over?

(In reply to comment #1) > Which page were you dragging over?
The XML editor that had "data.xml" open.

I did some further investigation.
The problem only occurs when "Link with Editor" is enabled in the view where the drag starts. When I enable "Link with Editor" in the Navigator view, it behaves the same way as the Package Explorer.
You can see a difference between the XML editor and the platform's text editor when "Link with Editor" is enabled:
- Drag a file over an open XML editor and the selection in the originating view changes - Drag a file over an open text editor and the selection in the originating view does _not_ change
It looks like the XML editor is executing the "Link with Editor" code when a drag is going on while the text editor does not. Hence the "infection" of the drag.

That was some very valuable digging you did there. My suspicion is that the difference is that the XML Editor provides a structured selection containing its DOM nodes and that the Package Explorer might be misinterpreting that selection as a list of files to use when you "drop". As you drag over the editor, it's updating its notion of selection and notifying listeners of those changes--I think the navigators may not be handling this interaction properly.
Automatic "Link with Editor" is implemented by the views, so I'm forwarding this to Platform UI.

Litrik, thanks for the effort (it's appreciated). I'm having a bit of a problem reproing this though...
I have the Package explorer open with 'link with editor' set and 'Foo.xml' open in the edtor. I drag 'bar.txt' into and through the XML editor, over the task bar (bringing up FFox) and drop it...and end up looking at 'bar.txt'.
Do I have the repro steps correct?

(In reply to comment #5) > Do I have the repro steps correct?
Yes.
I tried it myself once more and first I also had problems reproducing it.
- Start Eclipse - Open Navigator view - Select "Link with editor" - Open foo.xml in XML editor - Drag bar.xml over open XML editor - Nothing weird happens. The selection in the Navigator stays on bar.xml.
Then I did some more digging. This is what I did to reproduce it:
- Open foo.xml in XML editor - Make a change to foo.xml - Save foo.xml (without closing the editor) - Drag bar.xml over open XML editor - The selection in the Navigator moves to foo.xml. Continuing the drag into Firefox opens foo.xml
So the key seems to be that the editor must already have modified/saved the file.
Boy oh boy... this is getting weirder every day ;-)

(In reply to comment #6) > - The selection in the Navigator moves to foo.xml. Continuing the drag into
I think that's the key. Both org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.packageview.FileTransferDragAdapter.getResources() and org.eclipse.ui.views.navigator.NavigatorDragAdapter.getSelectedResources(int) operate on whatever's currently selected in the view at the time of the drop.

I agree but I'm still concerned about the behaviour of the operation; dragging 'bar.xml' (the current selection in the PE/Resource view) over the editor area should -not- be updating the view's selection (since the editor is presumably still showing 'foo.xml'). I'll look into this as well since we have clients that have implemented their own transfer types that probably have the same {broken} assumption that the selection doesn't change during the drag op.

dragOver inside of the XML editor's source page makes it react by moving the text cursor around inside the page. The change in cursor position would trigger a selection change and fire that to the selection service. The view's listening to the selection service, right?
Hmmm, what editor are you using for XML? When I open an XML file the editor I get doesn't track the cursor...

(In reply to comment #10) > Hmmm, what editor are you using for XML? When I open an XML file the editor I > get doesn't track the cursor...
The one provided as part of WTP, in the WST subproject.

bug.short_desc: [Undo] Edit > Add Bookmark... does not work

long_desc.thetext:
I20060906-1200
1. start fresh workspace 2. create simple project P 3. create simple file f 4. close the editor (the editor actions works) 5. Edit > Add Bookmark... ==> bookmark is not added
Susan, might this be casued by work done for bug 7691?

I'll assume it's caused by my work in this area, since the scenario works properly in the 3.2 maintenance stream. My interactive testing focused on the bookmark view and editor actions, so I missed this path.

Fixed in HEAD, >20060912.
When the marker dialogs were refactored to share a common superclass, the add bookmark dialog did not properly designate its marker type. The dialog was only used in the editor action codepath where the file is not open. (other codepaths simply use a prompter to prompt for bookmark name).
So in this codepath, the marker was created, but the marker type was generic (org.eclipse.core.resources.marker) rather than org.eclipse.core.resources.bookmark. Even though a marker was created (and it could be undone/redone), it would not show up in the bookmark view, and since it has no location, it normally wouldn't show up anywhere else either.
Fixed the dialog to set the marker type.
> The dialog was > only used in the editor action codepath where the file is not open. You mean the Edit > ... code path? Or does Platform UI have specific editor actions for creating bookmarks?

Yes, I meant the Edit... code path.
The problem surfaced if BookmarkPropertiesDialog is opened to create a bookmark. The only codepath for that scenario is the AddBookmarkAction, used by the navigator as the global action handler for Edit>Add Bookmark.

verified in I20060919-0010, WinXP. Although this bug addresses the navigator Edit>AddBookmark.. action, I tested these scenarios:
- add a bookmark to foo.java using the ruler - add a bookmark to foo.java from the navigator edit menu (bookmark with no location) - add a bookmark to foo.java from foo.java's Edit... menu
In all of these cases, the add bookmark succeeds, the bookmark appears in the bookmark view, and undo is available and working.

bug.short_desc: Undo / Redo marker actions not updated

long_desc.thetext:
I20060906-1200
If a file gets delete after adding/changing/removing a marker then the Undo and Redo actions are not updated and still show, e.g. Undo Add Task Redo Add Task
Executing the undo or redo does nothing (no feedback, no .log entry) and the undo and redo menu text remains the same and enabled.

the operation knows it's invalid, but the action handlers are not refreshed to indicate this. A temporary (M2) solution is to have the operation call operationChanged when its validity state changes. But the real solution will come with bug #87494, which may or may not be ready for M2.

Fixed in HEAD >20060912.
I think the proper solution for now is to implement IAdvancedUndoableOperation (and IAdvancedUndoableOperation2) so that validity is computed just before attempting to execute, undo, or redo the operation. This means the undo/redo actions will still be available in the menus, but the problem will be caught.
So the scenario will be: - add/change/remove a marker - delete the file - undo/redo will still show "Undo Add Task" (or whatever was last done with markers) - attempt to undo the operation and you will get an error saying that the resource no longer exists.
This is similar to how refactoring problems are discovered. For example, rename a method, then update the source file, then try to undo the method rename from the package explorer. The invalid state is discovered during the undo. The idea is that expensive validation is not done until the operation is attempted.
This fix is not an interim solution. It will always be appropriate to compute the status of the operation just before trying it. In M3, we may add some periodic validity checking so that the stack is occasionally purged without the user trying to perform the operation (see bug #87494). If this is done, the user would never have the undo or redo operation available.
Dani, are you comfortable with this level of validation since the problem is now caught and described?
Also note that the use case will be different in M3 because after deleting the file, "Undo delete file" would appear in the menu.
OK for me assuming that the dialog only comes one time and then the operation is removed from the stack and I can undo the next operation.

Dialog only comes up once. Operation is removed from stack, .... but.... Once the top operation is invalidated, the entire workbench undo context is invalidated. This is a conservative, workbench-wide policy until we are sure we can be smarter about validation. It does not affect the undo stack (if any) of the editor on that file.

verified in I20060919-0010, WinXP, with these scenarios: - add a task to foo.java using the ruler - delete foo.java - try to "Undo Add Task" - warning dialog says that undo cannot be completed because marker no longer exists.
- add a task to foo.java from the navigator edit menu (task with no location) - delete foo.java - try to "Undo Add Task" - warning dialog says that undo cannot be completed because marker no longer exists.
- add a task to foo.java from foo.java's Edit... menu - delete foo.java - try to "Undo Add Task" - warning dialog says that undo cannot be completed because marker no longer exists.
also each of these scenarios where the add task is followed by a delete task before deleting the resource. In this case, the "Undo Delete Task" has the same dialog when attempting it after deleting the resource.
also each of these scenarios where the add task is followed by an edit on the task's name. In this case the "Undo Modify Task" has the same dialog when attempting it after deleting the resource.

bug.short_desc: Multiple structure compare panes after 'Navigate > Next Difference'

long_desc.thetext:
N20060911-0010
Steps: - have org.eclipse.core.expressions from CVS - show /org.eclipse.core.expressions/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF in History view - select rev. 1.7 and 1.8 and choose context menu 'Compare with Each Other' - choose Navigate > Next Difference twice => same 'Manifest Structure Compare' pane is shown three times
Created an attachment (id=49824) Screenshot

Initial investigations have revealed that this bug is not new (i.e. it is not introduced by the changes we made this week) but has been in since, at least, I20060829. I suspect it is in 3.2 as well. However, only in HEAD does the navigate arrows seem to trigger the bug. In older builds, double clicking on the structure entry triggers the problem (although this could be due to a difference in settings between the workspaces I am using to test).

This is due to a problem in the dManifest strucutre creator. The MF type is being returned for the sub-nodes of the structure and this is causing the Structure view to be reshown. I will attach a patch that fixes the problem.

Created an attachment (id=50078) Patch to PDE/UI
This patch fixes the problem and also updates the Manifest viewers to use the new file buffer support. I noticed that there are classes related to XML compare but they are not actually used so I didn't modify them.

Thanks Michael.
I applied the patch and it solves the problem.
However, not having the original compare code myself, I am not sure what the MF2 extension means. It also seems that jdt has Java2 and properties2. what is the significance of the 2?

Compare uses a type (e.g. java) to determine what structured viewer and content viewer to use. The second type was added so that the sub element would match the content viewer but not the structured viewer.

bug.short_desc: API to create ITypeBinding from type name

long_desc.thetext:
3.2
As discussed on the JDT summit:
- find and create bindings in existing binding environments * find type binding by name or key
The API would be a generalization of AST#resolveWellKnownType(String), with the difference that type bindings can be resolved for all types on the classpath. The best home for the API would be the BindingEnvironment (see bug 150657).
The method could be
ITypeBinding resolveTypeBinding(String name)
and should work for primitive types, classes, interfaces, enums, and annotations. For generic types, the method should resolve to the type declaration (isGenericType() == true).

bug.short_desc: CDT Internal builder parallelization proposal

long_desc.thetext: At the moment, all project resources are built sequentially in their dependancy order. Thus advantages of modern multi-core processors are not used effectively. On the other hand, preliminary tests have demonstrated perfomance boost almost proportionate to the number of processors (or processor cores) in case of parallel build. The idea is to build simultaneously all resources which do not depend on each other.
Created an attachment (id=49827) CDT Internal builder parallelization proposal
So this would be like a -j make flag for the internal builder. Very cool. This is also something some has asked me about with the indexer as well.

Created an attachment (id=51333) Patch which implements parallel
Parallel build mode is implemented for internal builder, according to proposal in general.
Testing performed on x86-64 system with 2 Intel Xeon processors with hyperthreading enabled. Both Win2003 and RH EL4 have reported 4 physical processors.
Note: number of CPUs detected automatically both for Windows and Linux (not Mac yet) and used as "optimal jobs number". But user can change threads number by hand in Project Properties -> C/C++ Build -> Build settings page. Maximal jobs number is not limited.
Below is a table representing absolute and relative time for project build with different number of jobs(threads).
Standard code: 9.6 s 100% 1 thread 9.5 s 99% 2 threads 5.2 s 54% 4 threads 3.6 s 37.5% 8 threads 3.5 s 36.5% 16 threads 3.7 s 38.5%
We can see that maximum performance is achieved if number of threads is 8 (not equal to CPU number !). But it can differ for various kinds of projects.
On 1-processor system, performance does not depend of jobs number (approximately the same build time both for existing mode and parallel build with any number of jobs).

Please explain how it behaves.

You are right. Currently we're creating separate job for each project, and it creates jobs for every configurstion involved.
So number of resulting jobs cannot be set by user now, but it depends of selected projects and their configurations.
Moreover, build process for each configuration may be split to several threads depending on settings in "Builder Settings" property page.

Not yet. Do you really need them ?

bug.short_desc: Refreshing bundle with native library causes a library loading exception

long_desc.thetext:
PackageAdmin specification says that it will refresh all the bundles that are either updated or depending on updated bundles. It is enough to be included in the graph build by PackageAdmin for a bundle to be refreshed. This must cause assignement of a new classloader to a bundle. If such a bundle (not updated directly, but refreshed because one of the bundles it relied on was updated) contains a native library it will result in JVM error stating that the library was loaded by another classloader.
Possible solution would be to copy or move bundle files to another directory on refresh so the library could be loaded again by another classloader (as it is identified by Java by it's disk location)

I do not really like copying the complete content of the bundle each time a refresh is done even if the bundle contains no native code.
Seems like a better approach may be to keep track of when a native library was loaded. If an attempt to load it again occurs then copy it to a temp file and return that path.

A "copy-on-write" policy would be better (as Tom suggests). Everytime a bundle is refreshed, its native libs should be marked dirty. When then next findLibrary call is made, the dirty bit will tell the framework to make a copy to a new absolute path and return the new absolute path.

Sure. I'm not saying that it would be needed to be done each time. It could be quite easy to check whether bundle contains any native libraries.
Of course "lazy approach" is good as well. The temp file would have other name and would be located in the same dir? Any thoughts on it? Would it be located in temp dir?

The fix for this should be isolated to BaseData.findLibrary method.
Before returning the result we could add the native path string to a cache (Set). Each time findLibrary is called we would check to see if the result is in the cache. If it is then we know this library was loaded before, at this point we should copy the library located at the path to a temp file. We could have a templibs/ directory under the org.eclipse.osgi configuration area were we place the temp libs. We cannot just use the parent directory where the original library is located because this could be a directory under an extracted "directory" bundle which was installed by reference. In this case we do not want to add files to the plugin's directory.

Sounds good.
However we still need a way of avoiding potential naming conflicts in the templibs directory. File.createTempFile can be used but this would change the name of library itself. Other solution would be to create random directory in templibs and copy there. Then library name would be preserved.
We also need a way of cleaning this directory, most likely on a startup - I guess we don't want to have disk space leak here. What would be the best place for the cleaning code?

Created an attachment (id=50101) patch
Here is a patch to demostrate what I'm thinking.
- Each ClassPathManager (e.g. class loader) keeps track of the native code paths it finds. If the same library name is asked multiple times then it returns the previous path. This is required because you can call System.loadLibrary multiple times and it will only load it once for the calling classloader. In this case we do not want to copy on findLibrary.
- Each BundleData also keeps track of when findLibrary is called multiple times for the same library. If it is called more than once then we copy the found library to a tempdir and return the temporary path.
The double house keeping is needed so that we only copy library when a more than one classloader asks for the same library from the same BundleData object.
The patch needs some work. For some reason the libraries are not being cleaned up on exit even though I call File.deleteOnExit() for the temp file. I think this is because the library file is still locked by the VM when it loaded the library. We will need to do a compact operation on the templib dir on startup. This should be quick if the templib dir does not exist.
We also have some code that will set execution permissions on native code if a property is set. We should also do the same thing for the libraries we copy. I will finish off the patch if we agree this is the proper approach.
This type of solution would also help if we ever decide to allow fragments to attach to more than one hosts. In this case the same fragment could deliver native code to more than one host bundle.
Fix looks good. Is there any chance that this fix will make 3.2.x release? Our next release will be 3.2 based and we need this kind of functionality quite urgently.

Created an attachment (id=50562) patch
Here is a updated patch that addresses the remaining issues in comment 6, and adds some much needed comments to explain what we are doing. I will release this patch for 3.3 M3.
We have missed the release for 3.2.1. The patch will need some extra testing and review to before we can allow it to be released into 3.2.x. Either way it can not make it until 3.2.2 (I do not know the dates for that, but I would not expect it until 1Q 2007)
Jeff's approval will be needed to release this to 3.2.2.
released latest patch to HEAD for 3.3 M3.
Need some info on risk and reqiurements before committing to 3.2.2

Created an attachment (id=55163) 3.2.x patch
This is a patch against 3.2.x
I put this patch risk at medium. It is not just a small code change. The code has been in Eclipse 3.3 since before M3, but typical eclipse scenarios do not run into this situation. We have not seen any "bad" effects of the patch in 3.3. This code should only take effect if a bundle classloader is refreshed and it contains native code (something that currently fails in the current 3.2.1 release).
Jeff do you approave this fix for 3.2.2? Grzegorz is this fix still important to you? Can you wait til 3.3?
+1 if there are compelling usecases/needs to support the medium risk.
Thomas, Jeff, this fix is quite important for us as we will be basing our next release on LWI 7.1 containing Eclipse 3.2.x. So yes - we still do need it.
Fix released for 3.2.2.

bug.short_desc: [comments] More flexibility with handling trailing and/or leading comments needed.

long_desc.thetext:
My situation is the following: I am automatically processing a huge code base with the ASTRewriter, and in some cases I do not want that comments are deleted when the neighbouring statements are.
So, my wish would be to allow more flexibility. I don't really care how it is realized, but I would propose a strategy pattern, so that anybody can implement an own CommentMapping strategy object and influence the behaviour as needed. This way everybody can decide, which comments will move or delete together with the neighbouring node, and which comments stay in place.

bug.short_desc: URLStreamHandlerFactory stepping on previously installed handler

long_desc.thetext:
Are you setting
java.protocol.handler.pkgs=org.jboss.net.protocol
This VM property expects the prefix protocol packages to be available on the application classloader (stuff available from -classpath). Is the org.jboss.net.protocol package available on the app classloader in your environment?
I assume in your environment jboss is loaded from a classloader that is not one of the VMs built-in classloaders (boot, ext, app etc). Then it loads the equinox framework using the same classloader as jboss or in a separate classloader that uses the jboss classloader as its parent classloader. This means the jboss protocol handlers are available to both jboss and equinox but not to the VMs built-in classloaders.
There are a couple of possible solutions:
1) if jboss protocol handlers are not available in the VM's built-in classloaders then do not set the java.protocol.handler.pkgs property.
2) have the StreamHandlerFactory in Equinox ask the parent factory first, before checking for built-in VM handlers
3) Change the StreamHandlerFactory.getBuiltIn method to load built-in handlers from the application classloader instead of using the framework's classloader. In your env this should result in a CNFE causing us to search the OSGi registry and then the parent factory.
Option 1 is the current workaround, unless you are not currently setting that property. If that is the case then I do not understand why you are running into this issue.
Option 2 will cause other issues because we need to look in the service registry for a protocol handler first to properly handle mult-plexing more than one framework in a VM.
Option 3 is probably the ideal solution because it more accurrately mimics what the VM does when searching for a protocol handler from the java.protocol.handler.pkgs property.

I'm in agreement with Tom.
It would good to figure out exactly what's happening here, but the "java.protocol.handler.pkgs" property should not be set unless the class is available via the System (app) classloader. In your particular case, setting this property should not be necessary as the URLStreamHandlerFactory already set will catch this.
That said, I think we should probably look to improve the code in getBuiltin as you(Tom) mention to catch those situations where the bundle parent is "boot".

If jboss is not loaded by the application classloader then this seems like a jboss bug. The code also seems useless if they successfully set the URLStreamHandlerFactory to a factory that can load the jboss protocol handlers.

Created an attachment (id=49884) Option 3 patch attempt
Food for thought... Here's an option 3 type patch. I've added a loadSystemClass(...) method to SecureAction and then have the two HandlerFactories use it instead of secureAction.forName(...).

Thanks Simon. That is similar to what I was thinking. After a bit more thought ...
I'm wandering if we should just remove the getBuiltIn check StreamHandlerFactory. On most VMs the java.protocol.handler.pkgs is not set. This means by default we always check the registry and parent factory first for a protocol handler and return null to let the VM find one if we cannot. If we removed the getBuiltIn check then this would always be the behavior no matter what the java.protocol.handler.pkgs property was set to.
Unfortunately we cannot do the same thing in the ContentHandlerFactory because returning null causes us to never be called again (I love the consistency!! :) Perhaps we should move the logic to check the built in content handlers into ContentHandlerProxy.setNewHandler. If the service reference is null then try to load and create a built in handler to use instead of the DefaultContentHandler class.

Maybe. I think we'd have to do something pretty clever in the NullxxxHandlers otherewise we'll run into trouble when a URLService is unregistered for a built-in protocol.
Still... I've always felt a little uncomfortable with not allowing the possibility of overriding the built-ins.

Created an attachment (id=49997) updated patch
I tried out the patch and found a bug in how it searched for protocol handlers in the framework (e.g. reference, bunndleentry, bundlereference). We still need to do Class.forName calls for these protocols to be able to load them from the framework. Here is a fixed patch.
... in my defence I was already late for dinner ;) It looks good now. Thanks Tom.
I released a slightly modified patch. SecureAction needed to isolate the creation of the bootclassloader with a doPriv in the static initializer.

bug.short_desc: Define a content type for *.uml resources

long_desc.thetext:
My application is using APIs that identify workspace resources by content type, but org.eclipse.uml2.uml does not define a content-type for *.uml files. So, I attempted to define my own content type extending the Eclipse platform's xml content type.
This works fine, except that when my application and the org.eclipse.uml2.uml.editor plug-in are deployed in the same workbench, the default editor for *.uml files is the XML editor from WTP (because my UML content type extends XML content type). I could fix this by registering my content type against UML's editor, but then UML might change its preferred editor in the future (e.g., some editor in the new MDT project).
It would be better if the org.eclipse.uml2.uml plug-in, itself, defined the content type and associated it with the appropriate editor, so that my application can use it. For example, the following might be a reasonable content type definition:
<extension point="org.eclipse.core.runtime.contentTypes"> <content-type base-type="org.eclipse.core.runtime.xml" default-charset="UTF-8" file-extensions="uml" id="UMLContentType" name="UML content type" priority="high"/> </extension>
Created an attachment (id=50089) proposed changes
Waiting until support for content types is provided in EMF...

The Proposal for an Eclipse Model Registry available from CVS at
/cvsroot/technology/org.eclipse.gmt/umlx/plugins/org.eclipse.gmt.umlx.registry
introduces a model_content extension point:
<extension point="org.eclipse.gmt.umlx.registry.model_content"> <xml uri="http://schema.omg.org/spec/mof/2.0/emof.xmi" factory="org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi.impl.EMOFResourceFactoryImpl"/> <xml uri="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore" factory="org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi.impl.EcoreResourceFactoryImpl"/> </extension>
so that the URI of the root XML element can be bound to an appropriate factory, which is used when EcoreFamilyResourceSetImpl is used to load the resources. The file extension is then irrelevant.
A model_serialization extension point allows non-XML contents to be resolved as well.

bug.short_desc: Import CBE log does not show all events

long_desc.thetext: Driver: tptp.runtime-TPTP-4.2.1-200609071820A.zip Import the attached CBE log file that contains 4 CBE events, but when imported, only 2 events is shown.
Created an attachment (id=49831) CBE logs
The problem seems to be in the third event which contains special char, but I don't see any excpetion log anywhere.

Eugene, the log that you have provided is not UTF-8 encoded, it contains characters which are not UTF-8 and since the code runs the SaxParser to parse the log file it obviously fails. In 4.2 we were using the GLA to parse CBE XML logs and the GLA uses the system native encoding to read the source file and delegates the loader to create the model. Notice that the hex value of the problematic characters in the source file and in the imported file are different.

The CBE XML log is not a valid XML file, it doesn't have a start and end element. It just contains XML fragments so the parser assumes the encoding is UTF8 and it fails to parse the third event which has a message that contains non-ASCII characters (characters from the cp1252 code page).

Targetting to 4.2.1. The proposal is to back out the performance improvement for local log import of CommonBaseEvent XML log files that was added with bugzilla https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=151704 because it introduced this regression.
Fix checke din as per PMC approval.

bug.short_desc: Add support for UML 2.0 enumerations to OAW4.1 Classic

long_desc.thetext:
We would like to be able to use UML 2.0 enumerations in Classic mode. This probably requires changes to both the metamodel (Enumeration would be a subtype of Type, and would have an ordered collection of EnumerationLiterals) and the mapping file. Our application uses MagicDraw 11 and 11.5. This would enable a much cleaner use of enumerations for attributes than our present solution, which creates ad hoc stereotypes, e.g.,
myAttribute: String <<enumerated=ChoiceA!ChoiceB!ChoiceC>>
Real UML 2.0 enumerations could also be subclassed, something not possible with the above kludge.

Thus one gets the following compile error when integrating OAW into a build environment that uses the latest JDOM: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.jdom.Parent.addContent(ILorg/jdom/Content;)Lorg/jdom/Parent; at org.openarchitectureware.core.frontends.xmi.toolsupport.uml.magicdraw.MagicDrawModuleMerger.merge(MagicDrawModuleMerger.java:302)
I suggest that MagicDrawModuleMerger should be updated and that JDOM 1.0 should be included in OAW.

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] enhancements to ILazyTreeContentProvider

long_desc.thetext:
Based on ILazyTreeContentProvider 3.2, I would like to suggest the following enhancements be considered:
* Currently, a lazy tree content provider provides a child count for a parent, and updates each child by index. When a tree node is visible, but not expanded, it would be sufficient to ask a model element if it has children, rather than how many. It is sometimes more efficient for a model element to know that it has children, rather than determining exactly how many. Of course, when a node is expanded, asking it how many children it has is fine. (see related bug 156441).
* The lazy tree content provider is based on model elements (objects). However, since the standard JFace tree viewer supports multiple duplicate elements at different locations in the same tree (based on tree paths), the content provider should also have the option to retrieve/specify content by path rather than just model element. With the current API, every occurrence of a model element must have the same content.

about hasChildren():
The problem with this is the asynchronous nature of the content provider. To show a plus, the tree viewer code would have to create a dummy child node. If the content provider does not respond synchronously when the parent is expanded, it would either have to delete the dummy node momentarily when you click on the plus, or show the dummy node to the user. Deleting the dummy node would be bad, because the plus would go away, only to come back when the content provider is ready, and then you would have to click on it again. Unless it somehow marked it as being in the process of being expanded, but that feels like a hack, too.

Regarding "hasChildren"... could it not work the same as "updateChildCount". A call to "updateHasChildren" would call back to "setHasChildren". Until the call is made back to "setHasChildren" no dummy node is added into the tree. When expanded, a call is made to "updateChildCount".
Until the call to setChildCount comes back, what do we do with the dummy node?

I think the dummy node would just become the 1st child node. Expanded it would result in a 'setData' callback to update the child, and as well, you would ask the content provider to update the child count for that parent.

(In reply to comment #4) > I think the dummy node would just become the 1st child node. Expanded it would > result in a 'setData' callback to update the child, and as well, you would ask > the content provider to update the child count for that parent.
Thanks! I am starting to believe that we can do this.
Created an attachment (id=52073) work in progress

Created an attachment (id=52183) patch
Darin, could you give this a try?

I found one problem with the current patch: the implementation of "setChildCount(elementOrTreePath)" uses "findItems(...)" instead of "internalFindItems(...)". I think internalFindItems has to be used when the argument is a tree path.
I have a question/issue with the APIs that accept tree paths... When the viewer calls out to the content provider, an empty path identifies the root element. However, clients cannot call back into the tree with empty paths to identify the root element - instead the client has to call back in with the "root element". This feels inconsistent.
Oh, and it doesn't seem like ILazyTreePathContentProvider.updateHasChildren(...) is ever called yet?

As well, replace(....) should be done with a preserving selection, as children orders can change when updating children. (This is really an existing bug with the tree viewer, rather than one with this implementation).

Created an attachment (id=52243) updated patch
(In reply to comment #8) > I found one problem with the current patch: the implementation of > "setChildCount(elementOrTreePath)" uses "findItems(...)" instead of > "internalFindItems(...)". I think internalFindItems has to be used when the > argument is a tree path.
Yes. Thanks!
> I have a question/issue with the APIs that accept tree paths... When the viewer > calls out to the content provider, an empty path identifies the root element. > However, clients cannot call back into the tree with empty paths to identify > the root element - instead the client has to call back in with the "root > element". This feels inconsistent.
Agree.
> Oh, and it doesn't seem like > ILazyTreePathContentProvider.updateHasChildren(...) is ever called yet?
Oops...
> As well, replace(....) should be done with a preserving selection, as > children orders can change when updating children.
OK.
The updated patch should address your comments so far.

For comment#12 and comment#14, the update child count should likely only be performed when there is one dummy item. Else the client may already have updated the child count, and the tree will just be asking the client to do extra work.

bug.short_desc: DOMInspector: Performance enhancements when DOM changes

long_desc.thetext:
Might be a performance enhancement to only refresh the TreeViewer ONLY on DOMMutation Events that affect visible nodes. Right now, a call is made to refresh(node) regardless of whether the node is visible or not.
There are two possible calls that can be made on the TreeViewer, getExpandedNodes() or getVisibleExpandedNodes(). Not sure which one is best because the first one will return anything that is expanded regardless of whether the an anscestor is collapsed. This might be necessary because I think a call to the ContentProvider will not ocurr if the node is already expanded.

Upon investigating this I found that the width for the "Add Log File" dialog is unusually large because the "character encoding" drop-down requires this width in certain translations. There may be some small amount of reduction that can be done but this would only be for the EN-US encoding style.

bug.short_desc: Large log support should support Derby not Cloudscape

long_desc.thetext:
As per discussion with Harm, Derby is the open source database and Cloudscape is a productization of it. TPTP should support open source, not productizations.
This should be possible mostly through testing and updating some docs: http://help.eclipse.org/help32/topic/org.eclipse.tptp.platform.doc.user/tasks/tlglogpref.html
*** Bug 147363 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Upgrading the priority to match the priority of defect 147363.
*** Bug 160893 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Also update the readme that states that Derby 10.1 is not supported. (i.e., after this defect is implemented it will be supported and Cloudscape will not be supported.)
Upgrading to critical because the docs are misleading. The docs say that Cloudscape 10.0 is supported but in fact the scripts won't work with Cloudscape 10.0; instead they work with version 10.1.

I've found that switching from Cloudscape to Derby isn't as isolated a change as I thought. I had thought that I would need to update the documentation and change the name from "Cloudscape" to "Apache Derby" in some .properties file somewhere and that would be it, but there's more to it than that.
1. "Cloudscape" isn't in a .properties file. Instead it's hard-coded in the DB extension and it's used for more than the "database type" in the UI. It's used as the name of the .trcadb file and in the .trcadb file at least. This means that to change the "Cloudscape" to "Apache Derby" changes the actual behaviour of the code instead of just its display. 2. The name of the Derby jar that's used for network access is "derbyclient.jar" while for Cloudscape it's "db2jcc.jar". When I entered the patch to "derbyclient.jar" in the preference page the "Test Connection" button didn't enable until I had closed the preference page and then reopened it. Then when I reopened the page and clicked the button I got a connection error. I noticed some places in the code that look for "db2jcc.jar" and that code needs to be updated.
It's too risky to continue with this change for 4.3 i3. Instead I'll reopen Jane's defect (bugzilla 160893) so that I can change the docs to refer to Cloudscape 10.1 instead of 10.0. We know that 10.0 isn't supported and causes problems so for 4.3 we should at least identify the correct version of Cloudscape that is supported. (Derby in embedded mode appeared to work when I didn't change the name from "Cloudscape" to "Apache Derby".)
I am going to attach the updated doc files that remove all references to Cloudscape and replace them with Derby 10.1.1.0. When Derby 10.1.1.0 is supported these doc files should be checked in and the existing ones should be removed.

Reducing to major and deferring since the critical doc updates will be done under bugzilla 160893.
Estimate : 24 hrs

The code is checked into the CVS, please let me know if it fixes your problem.

bug.short_desc: [Usability] Poor usability when importing log files

long_desc.thetext:
Recently an enhancement was implemented to be able to select multiple log files for import through the browse button of the "Add log file" dialog. This enhancement wasn't well thought through and it introduces a lot of unnecessary dialogs. It also increases the complexity for users who wish to only import a single log file.
The current use case is:
1) User select File > Import > Profiling and Logging > Log File > Next > Add 2) Click browse > browse > traverse through file system to find log file directory > ok > check log files to be imported > ok > ok > finish
The new enhancement caused the complexity in 2). The maximum number of dialogs displayed during this process is 4 (see snap1) very messy. Here's a simple point system that should help evaluate the complexity of a use case:
a) Every single click should cost 5 points b) Every double click costs 8 points c) Every dialog opened costs 15 points
Step number 2) alone costs us a minimum of 7*5 + 15*4 = 95 points. A good use case should only have 50-60 points in total. We need to re-evaluate this recent enhancement that was added in 4.2 and reduce the complexity of the use case.
Created an attachment (id=49846) Importing log files
Deferring to 4.4. It cannot be addressed at this point of the 4.3 schedule.
Target to future. Cannot be contained in 4.4 due to limitation of resource.
Move target back to 4.4. Monitor defects are mistakenly targeted in bulk move.
Targetting to future as it cannot be contained in 4.4.
Just need an extension point to provide a new import wizard from AC perspective.
This is required from the AC perspective via extension points.
